author: Geoff Herbert | gherbert@syracuse.com
title: J-Law slams gender wage gap; 'Friday the 13th' video game; 'Glee' reboot: PM Buzz
text:
Comments 
"Hunger Games" star Jennifer Lawrence is upset with the gender wage gap after Sony hacks reveal she and and Amy Adams made much less money than "the lucky people with d---s" in "American Hustle," Christian Bale and Bradley Cooper. The 25-year-old actress said it's her fault for not wanting to seem "difficult" or "spoiled" during salary negotiations, but says seeing her male co-stars' payrolls made her realize men don't have the same concerns. "Are we socially conditioned to behave this way?" J-Law asked. "Could there still be a lingering habit of trying to express our opinions in a certain way that doesn't 'offend' or 'scare' men?" » Read more at the Daily Mail . 
A "Friday the 13th" video game is in the works, where players can be Jason Voorhees and kill half-naked campers with a machete and other weapons. The third-person multiplayer video game would pit the legendary slasher against seven Camp Crystal Lake counselors after a previously announced "Slasher Vol.1: Summer Camp" reached an agreement with the horror franchise. To make it happen, though, a Kickstarter campaign is seeking $700,000 in donations by Nov. 13 -- Friday the 13th. 
Don't stop believing: A "Glee" reboot will happen in Lea Michele gets her way. The 29-year-old actress flaunted her abs on the cover of Women's Health magazine for a cover story interview where she said she hopes the musical TV series comes back, possibly as a revival on Netflix or Hulu, with a role for her. Michele has nothing to worry about, though, as she's currently starring on "Glee" creator Ryan Murphy's latest over-the-top show, "Scream Queens." » Read more at the New York Daily News . 
And if you're sick of remakes and reboots, a slew of new TV shows are in the works. First, Jack Black and Dwight Yoakam are producing a new Nashville sitcom called " Belles & Whistles ," about a Silicon Valley dad who moves his family in hopes of launching a music career. Next, Bruno Mars will produce a NBC sitcom with "Empire" executive producer Brian Grazer about a "loud, boisterous" musical family from the Bronx. And "Game of Thrones" writer George R.R. Martin's next series will be "The Skin Trade," a Cinemax series based on his "offbeat 'werewolf noir' novella" about "a collections agent who happens to be a werewolf." » Read more about "The Skin Trade" at Esquire .
